document.title: The Ontario Curriculum Grades 1-8: Science and Technology, 2007

C37C20639C0E442FA62091D43CA46663.description:
explain changes in atmospheric conditions
caused by the presence of bodies of water
(e.g., differences in temperature near large
bodies of water; microclimates; storms off
coastal areas)

E918977333374C9793578E97F966D8D7.description:
identify factors (e.g., annual precipitation, temperature,
climate change) that affect the size of
glaciers and polar ice-caps, and describe the
effects of these changes on local and global
water systems

98CB98B21AD6400EAE06E21AC942AFC6.description:
explain how human and natural factors cause
changes in the water table (e.g., lawn watering,
inefficient showers and toilets, drought, floods,
overuse of wells, extraction by bottled water
industry

03506D2CF2804535A31A5374DA496057.description:
demonstrate an understanding of the watershed
as a fundamental geographic unit, and
explain how it relates to water management
and planning

092DE43519CD42C98552AED152AAE03C.description:
identify the various states of water on the earth’s
surface, their distribution, relative amounts, and
circulation, and the conditions under which
they exist (e.g., water is a solid in glaciers, snow,
and polar ice-caps; a liquid in oceans, lakes, rivers,
and aquifers; and a gas in the atmosphere)

5B877149C4AA45BEAC0374F81AFFE689.description:
use a variety of forms (e.g., oral, written, graphic,
multimedia) to communicate with different
audiences and for a variety of purposes
(e.g. using appropriate scientific conventions,
draw a labelled diagram of a water treatment
facility; create a brochure about the safe use
of wells and septic tanks)

181DE948906B41BD90945226D37976D7.description:
use appropriate science and technology
vocabulary, including water table, aquifer,
polar ice-cap, and salinity, in oral and
written communication

37208CE2643349209C53C528D65A4FAB.description:
use technological problem-solving skills (see
page 16) to design, build, and test a water system
device that performs a practical function
or meets a need

70B0651E3BF346249FDB2D2BE36AB414.description:
use scientific inquiry/research skills (see
page 15) to investigate local water issues

1425E0CEB031417C946C37FA5A2D663C.description:
test water samples for a variety of chemical
characteristics (e.g., pH, salinity, chlorine)

19ECBF4284304BD0A547844C8035476C.description: investigate how municipalities process water (e.g., obtain it, test it, and treat it) and manage water (e.g., distribute it, measure consumption, and dispose of waste water)

764B38723AA04FAEA3CCEB0F1B264ABB.description:
follow established safety procedures for the use
of apparatus and chemicals (e.g., when using
water-testing equipment and water-testing
chemicals)

CE6A1E7A39F94F2F8F4A4B53EA0A5D34.description:
assess the impact on local and global water
systems of a scientific discovery or technological
innovation (e.g., enhancing the efficiency
of naturally occurring bacteria that consume
hydrocarbons from oil spills and convert them
to carbon dioxide and water; development of
desalination techniques to provide fresh water
from sea water)

47A623B1091A443BAD6C000D2B3C8D45.description: assess how various media sources (e.g., Canadian Geographic; the science section in newspapers; Internet websites; local, national, and international news on television and radio) address issues related to the impact of human activities on the long-term sustainability of local, national, or international water systems

4287BF0E03E247B6ABB47652F66113F2.description:
evaluate personal water consumption, compare
it with personal water consumption in other
countries, and propose a plan of action to
reduce personal water consumption to help
address water sustainability issues

2B12F19B5CCF4662993439BCE73049AF.description:
Relating Science and Technology
to Society and the Environment

24A78269DBDF47B88E56370CA17C146B.description: demonstrate an understanding of the characteristics of the earth’s water systems and the influence of water systems on a specific region.

A956486F800A4CDC8F440510843EDAB7.description: investigate factors that affect local water quality;

C854BEB9213146B39ED03652B4B4D464.description: assess the impact of human activities and technologies on the sustainability of water resources;

D4488EC20A894E929B98D07B6DCEE9C4.description: Overall Expectations,  By the end of Grade 8, students will:

371F1653EC574ED49CDC08B21DF2A4D0.description: Understanding Earth and Space Systems: Water Systems

F8F48105E08D44E9989060042BF216BA.description: compare the ways in which fluids are used and controlled in living things to the ways in which they are used and controlled in manufactured devices (e.g., compare the role of valves in the circulatory system to the role of valves in an internal combustion engine; compare the role of a fish’s swim bladder to the role of the ballast tanks in a submarine)

FCE43803D8DD425294E69B4AE0A65B00.description: explain how forces are transferred in all directions in fluids (Pascal’s law)

4B26DD9A653E4C47BB26ADB60067FFA2.description: explain in qualitative terms the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature when a liquid (e.g., water) or a gas (e.g., air) is compressed or heated

6599777358BF4297B1D4D918F3C64B00.description: determine the buoyancy of an object, given its density, in a variety of fluids (e.g., less dense objects float, more dense objects sink)

C19AF7E3587E435994DE85CE23E2B122.description:
explain the difference between liquids and
gases in terms of their compressibility
(e.g., gases are more compressible than liquids)
and how their compressibility affects their
usage (e.g., pneumatic devices are used to operate
bus doors because they work over a larger
temperature range and are safer for this purpose
than hydraulic devices)

68097D9D6BA14D8AA752A15D60EDB53B.description: explain the difference between solids, liquids, and gases in terms of density, using the particle theory of matter (e.g., in general, solids are more dense than liquids, which are more dense than gases)

68C5E96A7B3A495CAB9CE2DC841368EE.description: describe the relationship between mass, volume, and density as a property of matter

C6E2C1AB195344AE9EC491894A00E0F4.description:
demonstrate an understanding of viscosity
and compare the viscosity of various liquids
(e.g., water, syrup, oil, shampoo, ketchup)

3BD7FE240BA344759EB1BA961DC9FB4A.description: use a variety of forms (e.g., oral, written, graphic, multimedia) to communicate with different audiences and for a variety of purposes (e.g., using appropriate scientific and/or technological conventions, create a technical drawing of a pneumatic/hydraulic device; create a brochure or a multimedia presentation outlining safe and unsafe uses of the device that was modelled)

0922556481CA413089FFCE2B9128BE56.description:
use appropriate science and technology vocabulary,
including viscosity, density, particle theory
of matter, hydraulic, and pneumatic, in oral and
written communication

A9FADE0A3848410F8D19F711110F788C.description:
use technological problem-solving skills (see
page 16) to design, build, and test devices that
use pneumatic or hydraulic systems

CB36D45E17414608B3C5127275F64D45.description: use scientific inquiry/experimentation skills (see page 12) to identify factors that affect the flow rates of various fluids

B83192C263134597800EF2916C6DE2AE.description:
investigate applications of the principles of
fluid mechanics (e.g., in aeronautical research,
shipping, food services, plumbing, hydrodynamic
engineering)

4D7F8A6B4DD945DEA647BD9BE6C4321F.description: investigate and compare the density of a variety of liquids (e.g., water, salt water, corn syrup, liquid soap)

87F511772B74454A81A8446C5B35AF5F.description: determine the mass-to-volume ratio of different amounts of the same substance (e.g., water, corn syrup, copper pennies)

BE83F90FEA034D7E85C176C976FCF31D.description:
follow established safety practices for using
apparatus, tools, and materials (e.g., use
syringes and tubing for the purposes for which
they were designed)

2AD08D32DDD0487BA35C22E800826DBB.description:
assess the impact of fluid spills on society and
the environment, including the cost of the
cleanup and the effort involved

3FBC1501F4A842AEA770C386A44CA27E.description:
assess the social, economic, and environmental
impacts of selected technologies that are based
on the properties of fluids

27A75059CB774521B799BD9DEC06AD4F.description:
Relating Science and Technology
to Society and the Environment

8927DE99B5F642C5A81C1913DF1146C3.description: demonstrate an understanding of the properties and uses of fluids.

FA8D0599B2554C1DA7615BA46F9F3D34.description: analyse how the properties of fluids are used in various technologies, and assess the impact of these technologies on society and the environment;

300549AF52714E3EB4341BD3C363E7E0.description: Overall Expectations By the end of Grade 8, students will:

9190A9D3F2C449439FD7468EF94E46D2.description: identify social factors that influence the evolution of a system (e.g., growing concern over the amount of waste creates a need for recycling centres, and the recycling centres must grow as population and waste increase; the desire to make tasks easier creates a need for pulley systems, gear systems, and hydraulic and pneumatic systems; changes in traditional work hours created by technological advances can influence changes in a child care system)

ADB5132E35574F7FBF355EC354672560.description: describe systems that have improved the productivity of various industries (e.g., robotic systems have increased the rate of production in factories that assemble the fine parts of wrist watches)

6844C3A2A6D7470080633E02F5AEB69D.description: explain ways in which mechanical systems produce heat, and describe ways to make these systems more efficient (e.g., friction produces heat, which can be reduced by lubrication)

FEA34836F2734A80BAD47D12B2A20109.description: calculate the mechanical advantage (MA = force needed without a simple machine divided by force needed with a simple machine) of various mechanical systems (e.g., a wheelbarrow allows a smaller force to lift a larger weight, a hockey stick allows a short movement of hands to move the blade a larger distance, a simple fixed pulley system redirects the effort force)

68D19B82BFDA421098E255BBB4999D24.description:
understand and use the formula
work = force × distance (W = F × d) to
establish the relationship between work,
force, and distance moved parallel to the
force in simple systems

CB2B5F95824E4F64B2A23F7044DD96E1.description: compare, using examples, the scientific definition with the everyday use of the terms work, force, energy, and efficiency

542D4D907EFC448C9A747A9FC8724979.description: identify the various processes and components of a system (e.g., robot, front-end loader/backhoe, heating system, transportation system, health care system) that allow it to perform its function efficiently and safely

77E82921C64A4DA69BF90EEC2DA1ED6B.description: identify the purpose, inputs, and outputs of various systems (e.g., a garden – purpose: to grow things; input: seeds, water, fertilizer; output: flowers, food)

42344BF1B59341E7B92623A917A52292.description:
identify various types of systems (e.g., mechanical
systems, body systems, optical systems, mass
transit systems, Aboriginal clan systems, health
care systems)

239926B6985444EFA0053847EEA69F76.description: use a variety of forms (e.g., oral, written, graphic, multimedia) to communicate with different audiences and for a variety of purposes (e.g., using appropriate mathematical conventions, create a graph to represent changes in mechanical advantage when certain factors in a mechanism are manipulated)

6CBAF79659ED4EE196947465BA554BE4.description:
use appropriate science and technology vocabulary,
including mechanical advantage, input,
output, friction, gravity, forces, and efficiency,
in oral and written communication

F4617A760D4646F38385D852A9DB7A1E.description:
investigate the information (e.g., owner’s manual
for a car, weather advisories for a region,
pest forecasts/warnings for a crop/region) and
support (e.g., a technical support line for computers)
provided to consumers/clients to
ensure that a system functions safely and
effectively

AF77A29D387E47689336933E88AED15F.description:
use technological problem-solving skills (see
page 16) to investigate a system (e.g., an optical
system, a mechanical system, an electrical system)
that performs a function or meets a need

620D401249DC4AA0A29EB819A6B25EE4.description: use scientific inquiry/experimentation skills (see page 12) to investigate mechanical advantage in a variety of mechanisms and simple machines

0684A51A1F5C42ECBF5023E6E0D2EC3A.description: investigate the work done in a variety of everyday activities and record the findings quantitatively (e.g., calculate the work done when lifting dumbbells by measuring the force required to move the dumbbell and multiplying by the distance the dumbbell moves)

51FD41373AAC42B6B8C2934DEC7CA39A.description:
follow established safety procedures for
working with apparatus, tools, materials,
and electrical systems (e.g., tie hair back
before working with drills, saws, and sanders) s

3BA4AEE745244975BA6BA8896AC356A0.description:
assess the impact on individuals, society, and
the environment of alternative ways of meeting
needs that are currently met by existing
systems, taking different points of view into
consideration

55860ED494674FA49987C0E5D5595454.description:
assess the social, economic, and environmental
impacts of automating systems

AF767F894F4B41B18D3A51FFAD0CACC4.description:
Relating Science and Technology
to Society and the Environment

FE44A83882D444D5BF1F67B830E33A69.description: demonstrate an understanding of different types of systems and the factors that contribute to their safe and efficient operation.

BD8CED7DF43E4B6CA0870BF7B91649CF.description: investigate a working system and the ways in which components of the system contribute to its desired function;

52A808F57319474AB24328701A6993A4.description:
assess the personal, social, and/or environmental impacts of a system, and evaluate
improvements to a system and/or alternative ways of meeting the same needs;

171BE57E27E64BCB832A936F415BDDF1.description: Overall Expectations, By the end of Grade 8, students will:

8A8137138C0D4F6FBDCD3A07F16EF480.description: Understanding Structures and Mechanisms: Systems in Action

E467AEC773C741B9B05FA3BC77439FFF.description: describe the organization of cells into tissues, organs, and systems (e.g., groups of cells with similar functions combine to make up tissues; groups of tissues with similar functions combine to make organs; groups of organs work together as organ systems)

32276C9DCC1947A8BF833FF94911EFF6.description: identify unicellular organisms (e.g., amoebae) and multicellular organisms (e.g., invertebrates [worms], vertebrates [frogs]), and compare ways in which they meet their basic needs (e.g., nutrition, movement, gas exchange)

1BBADEB6C77245BFA043E541404753F0.description:
explain the processes of diffusion and osmosis
and their roles within a cell

D7FB230BE8F547679ADA66711DDD021D.description:
compare the structure and function of plant
and animal cells

12E35F87798B4C03B548D5A4CF3A9290.description:
identify structures and organelles in cells,
including the nucleus, cell membrane, cell
wall, chloroplasts, vacuole, mitochondria, and
cytoplasm, and explain the basic functions of
each (e.g., the nucleus holds all the information
needed to make every cell in the body)

B3ED5A2A3CD048F4BC8214E23AC334E3.description:
demonstrate an understanding of the postulates
of the cell theory (e.g., the cell is the basic unit
of life; all cells come from pre-existing cells; all
living things are made up of one or more cells)

B317AB59EC0245AC946CA84592EDABEA.description:
use a variety of forms (e.g., oral, written, graphic,
multimedia) to communicate with different
audiences and for a variety of purposes
(e.g., using the conventions of science, make
a labelled drawing of a cell; create a slide show
to explain the results of investigations into the
processes of osmosis and diffusion)

9E8C502E97D6442AAD55F46631D8E08D.description:
use appropriate science and technology vocabulary,
including organelle, diffusion, osmosis, cell
theory, selective permeability, membrane, stage,
and eyepiece, in oral and written communication

BEBB87200C10465FB6D619CAA748BAF1.description:
use scientific inquiry/experimentation skills
(see page 12) to investigate the processes of
osmosis and diffusion

0AB313E74C424DB484B5F2F963373327.description:
prepare dry- and wet-mount slides of a variety
of objects for use with a microscope (e.g., a
piece of newspaper, a hair)

C7CACCF73F714A5B99A1E90888862B56.description:
use a microscope correctly and safely to find
and observe components of plant and animal
cells (e.g., using an onion slice or a prepared
slide of a protist) and make accurate drawings
of their observations

DD185218C7F3418D921E9FF3DE6A4DA2.description:
follow established safety procedures for handling
apparatus and materials (e.g., wash hands
after preparing materials for slides) and use
microscopes correctly and safely (e.g., carry the
microscope with both hands, place it near the
centre of the desk, ensure that the sun cannot
be directly focused through the instrument when
sunlight is used for illumination, keep both eyes
open when viewing to avoid eye strain)

655F5653F0F04E8DBBD1EF9ED515DB66.description: assess the potential that our understanding of cells and cell processes has for both beneficial and harmful effects on human health and the environment, taking different perspectives into account (e.g., the perspectives of farmers, pesticide manufacturers, people with lifethreatening illnesses)

08060ED15B4E429DB1910F29B502E69B.description:
assess the role of selected technologies
(e.g., the development of the electron microscope,
the ability to infuse dyes into cells, in vitro fertilization)
in enhancing our understanding of
cells and cellular processes

92551E5D00534DBA8A1E563DF02EA325.description:
Relating Science and Technology
to Society and the Environment

B5522706103B4213A649F7EF79814854.description: demonstrate an understanding of the basic structure and function of plant and animal cells and cell processes.

44B3B04D6B384163BE5131222D607D67.description: investigate functions and processes of plant and animal cells;

9F88B7BC635A47D7A1071BDA5A20388A.description: assess the impact of cell biology on individuals, society, and the environment;

AF156851A79645EAA64D1DF0D8C3D862.description: Overall Expectations, By the end of Grade 8, students will:
